items.title: The Political Price Shock of Data Centers and Electric Bills
items.summary: Democrats zeroed in on utilities and affordability to win Republican support in upset elections in Georgia and Virginia. Can the same playbook work in 2026?

items.title: Remembering WW2 Camps, Japanese Americans Fight Trump’s Immigration Crackdown
items.summary: Japanese Americans are seeing parallels between the government’s incarceration of their families during World War II and the current detention of Latinos.

items.title: 4 Dead After Shooting at Banquet Hall in California
items.summary: The shooting in Stockton, a city in California’s Central Valley, left 10 others wounded. The authorities said they were looking for a suspect.

items.title: Trump Frees Fraudster Just Days Into Seven-Year Prison Sentence
items.summary: David Gentile had been found guilty for his role in what prosecutors described as a $1.6 billion scheme that defrauded thousands of investors.

items.title: Webster Springs, W.Va. United In Grief Over Death of National Guard Specialist Sarah Beckstrom
items.summary: In Webster Springs, everyone knows one another. When National Guard Specialist Sarah Beckstrom was killed, that connection was even further strengthened.

items.title: Top Trump Aides to Meet With Ukrainians in Florida on Sunday
items.summary: Secretary of State Marco Rubio, Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner plan to discuss peace terms again after an uproar over a 28-point proposal drafted with Russian input.

items.title: ‘We have become so divided’: Georgia district prepares for life after Marjorie Taylor Greene
items.summary: <p>Republicans and Democrats alike look to fill congressional firebrand’s House seat when she departs in 2026</p><p>Marjorie Taylor Greene for president. Randy Bone rolled the idea around in his hands for a second as he stood inside his wife’s antique shop in Ringgold, Georgia. He’s heard the talk. He’s even seen the prediction market action. He doesn’t have a problem with his boisterous, attention-seeking congresswoman.

items.title: Power surge: law changes could soon bring balcony solar to millions across US
items.summary: <p>Tweaks to state laws mean many Americans will be able to benefit from small, simple plug-in solar panels</p><p>Acquiring solar panels at home can be an expensive hassle for people in the US. But small, simple, plug-in solar panels for use on balconies are soon to become available for millions of Americans, with advocates hoping the technology will quickly go mainstream.</p><p>Earlier this year, Utah became the first state in the country to pass legislation allowing people to purchase and install small, portable solar panels that plug into a standard wall socket.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/30/balcony-solar-power-states-laws">Continue reading...</a>
